prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RXCJ1504 CO(1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose observations of RXCJ1504 at CO(1-0) to map the distribution of molecular gas and its velocity structure on the same spatial scales as cooling X-ray filaments, star formation regions and rising X-ray cavities.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose observations of RXCJ1504 at CO(1-0) to map the distribution of molecular gas and its velocity structure on the same spatial scales as cooling X-ray filaments, star formation regions and rising X-ray cavities. At the redshift z=0.21 of RXCJ1504, the CO(1-0) line lies in band 3 at 94.9 GHz. ALMA Cycle 0 (McNamara et al. 2013, Russell et al. 2013) and OVRO (Edge & Frayer 2003) imaging have shown that most molecular gas roughly follows the the dust and Halpha emission lying within 5-8 arcsec of the centers of both objects (see Fig. 2). We require a spatial resolution of 0.45 arcsec to map the narrow, extended filaments and resolve their velocity structure. The maximum recoverable scale will be ~8 arcsec at CO(1-0), providing sharp images over all scales of interest. A single ALMA pointing meets our requirements. The CO(1-0) line will be covered in a single FDM 1.875 GHz baseband with the remaining three TDM 2 GHz basebands to observe the mm-continuum. Based on single dish CO observations, we do not expect strong continuum emission (<5 mJy) and will use the full 8GHz bandwidth to maximise the sensitivity. Continuum imaging will determine the strength and morphology of the emission, search for variability and possibly enable a self-calibration of the data.
The required sensitivity is dictated by the ability to detect and map broad velocity gas flows, similar to those observed in Cycle 0 observations of Abell 1664 and Abell 1835, at or above 4sigma significance. The gas flow in Abell 1835 involves ~1/5 of the total molecular gas mass, corresponding to 7x10^9 Msolar in RXCJ1504. RXCJ1504 is detected at CO(1-0) in an IRAM single dish observation with a total integrated flux of 3.63 Jykm/s and FWHM~300 km/s. Based on an outflow of ~1/5 of the total mass, we expect an outflow flux of 0.71 Jykm/s. For velocity channels of 80 km/s and line widths of 400 km/s, we will detect a bipolar outflow in two regions (eg., Fig. 1) requiring an rms sensitivity of 0.25 mJy to ensure a SNR of at least 4 per resolution element. For narrower line widths, such as the north-west component of the A1835 flow, we will be able to trace a flow over several spatial regions at high significance. We require a 1.5 hr observation at CO(1-0) for RXCJ1504, including calibrators and overhead, to achieve the required sensitivity. Based on CASA simdata simulations and Cycle 0 experience, this observation will provide sufficient uv-coverage to image the extended structure.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RXCJ1504 CO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose observations of RXCJ1504 at CO(3-2) to resolve nuclear disks, accelerating gas flows and other small-scale structures lying within a few arcseconds of the AGN.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose observations of RXCJ1504 at CO(3-2) to resolve nuclear disks, accelerating gas flows and other small-scale structures lying within a few arcseconds of the AGN. At the redshift z=0.21 of RXCJ1504, the CO(3-2) line lies in band 7 at 284.5 GHz. We require a spatial resolution of 0.15 arcsec to search for circumnuclear molecular disks and accelerating outflows. Based on the width of the Halpha emission peak and the size of molecular gas disks observed in A1664 and A1835 in ALMA Cycle 0, we expect a maximum scale of 3 arcsec and therefore the proposed observations will encompass the scales of interest. Any larger scale disk structure will be detected in the CO (1-0) observations. A single ALMA pointing meets our requirements. The CO(3-2) line will be covered in a single FDM 1.875 GHz baseband with the remaining three TDM 2 GHz basebands to observe the mm-continuum. Based on single dish CO observations, we do not expect strong continuum emission (<5 mJy) and will use the full 8GHz bandwidth to maximise the sensitivity. Continuum imaging will determine the strength and morphology of the emission, search for variability and possibly enable a self-calibration of the data.
The required sensitivity is dictated by the ability to detect and map the velocity structure of any disk or outflow. Although there are no CO (3-2) single dish observations of RXCJ1504, we have estimated the peak and total flux densities based on the observed flux density ratio of CO(3-2)/CO (1-0)~4.5 found for similar systems in Edge (2001) and our Cycle 0 Alma targets. Therefore we expect a total integrated flux of 16.3 Jykm/s and a FWHM~300km/s comparable to the CO(1-0) observations. For 20 independent spatial regions and velocity widths lying between 20-300 km/s, we require an rms sensitivity of 0.7 mJy to reach a minimum 4 sigma detection per resolution element and to constrain the line profile of gas through any disk. We therefore request a 1.3hr observation at CO(3-2) for RXCJ1504. Based on CASA simdata simulations and Cycle 0 experience, this observation will provide sufficient uv-coverage to image the extended structure.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RXJ0821 CO(1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose observations of RXJ0821 at CO(1-0) to map the distribution of molecular gas and its velocity structure on the same spatial scales as cooling X-ray filaments, star formation regions and rising X-ray cavities.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose observations of RXJ0821 at CO(1-0) to map the distribution of molecular gas and its velocity structure on the same spatial scales as cooling X-ray filaments, star formation regions and rising X-ray cavities. At the redshift z=0.10 of RXJ0821, the CO(1-0) line lies in band 3 at 103.8 GHz. ALMA Cycle 0 (McNamara et al. 2013, Russell et al. 2013) and OVRO (Edge & Frayer 2003) imaging have shown that most molecular gas roughly follows the the dust and Halpha emission lying within 5-8 arcsec of the centers of both objects (see Fig. 2). We require a spatial resolution of 0.45 arcsec to map the narrow, extended filaments and resolve their velocity structure. The maximum recoverable scale will be ~8 arcsec at CO(1-0), providing sharp images over all scales of interest. A single ALMA pointing meets our requirements. The CO(1-0) line will be covered in a single FDM 1.875 GHz baseband with the remaining three TDM 2 GHz basebands to observe the mm-continuum. Based on single dish CO observations, we do not expect strong continuum emission (<5 mJy) and will use the full 8GHz bandwidth to maximise the sensitivity. Continuum imaging will determine the strength and morphology of the emission, search for variability and possibly enable a self-calibration of the data.
The required sensitivity is dictated by the ability to detect and map broad velocity gas flows, similar to those observed in Cycle 0 observations of Abell 1664 and Abell 1835, at or above 4sigma significance. The gas flow in Abell 1835 involves ~1/5 of the total molecular gas mass, corresponding to 3x10^9 Msolar in RXJ0821. RXJ0821 is detected at CO(1-0) in an IRAM single dish observation with a total integrated flux of 6.4 Jykm/s and FWHM~130 km/s. Based on an outflow of ~1/5 of the total mass, we expect an outflow flux of 1.3 Jykm/s and expect a broader linewidth of ~400 km/s. For velocity channels of 80 km/s and line widths of 400 km/s, we will detect a bipolar outflow in two regions (eg., Fig. 1) requiring an rms sensitivity of 0.4 mJy to ensure a SNR of at least 4 per beam. For narrower line widths, such as the north-west component of the A1835 flow, we will be able to trace a flow over several spatial regions at high significance. We require a 45 min observation at CO(1-0) for RXJ0821, including calibrators and overhead, to achieve the required sensitivity. Based on CASA simdata simulations and Cycle 0 experience, this observation will provide sufficient uv-coverage to image the extended structure.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RXJ0821 CO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose observations of RXJ0821 at CO(3-2) to resolve nuclear disks, accelerating gas flows and other small-scale structures lying within a few arcseconds of the AGN.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose observations of RXJ0821 at CO(3-2) to resolve nuclear disks, accelerating gas flows and other small-scale structures lying within a few arcseconds of the AGN. At the redshift z=0.10 of RXJ0821, the CO(3-2) line lies in band 7 at 311.5 GHz. We require a spatial resolution of 0.15 arcsec to search for circumnuclear molecular disks and accelerating outflows. Based on the width of the Halpha emission peak and the size of molecular gas disks observed in A1664 and A1835 in ALMA Cycle 0, we expect a maximum scale of 3 arcsec and therefore the proposed observations will encompass the scales of interest. Any larger scale disk structure will be detected in the CO (1-0) observations. A single ALMA pointing meets our requirements. The CO(3-2) line will be covered in a single FDM 1.875 GHz baseband with the remaining three TDM 2 GHz basebands to observe the mm-continuum. Based on single dish CO observations, we do not expect strong continuum emission (<5 mJy) and will use the full 8GHz bandwidth to maximise the sensitivity. Continuum imaging will determine the strength and morphology of the emission, search for variability and possibly enable a self-calibration of the data.
The required sensitivity is dictated by the ability to detect and map the velocity structure of any disk or outflow. Although there are no CO(3-2) single dish observations of RXJ0821, we have estimated the peak and total flux densities based on the observed flux density ratio of CO(3-2)/CO (1-0)~4.5 found for similar systems in Edge (2001) and our Cycle 0 Alma targets. Therefore, we expect a total integrated flux of 28.7 Jykm/s and a FWHM~150-200 km/s comparable to the CO(1-0) observations. For 20 spatial regions and velocity widths of 20-200 km/s, we require an rms sensitivity of 0.7 mJy to ensure a minimum 4 sigma detection per resolution element and to constrain the line profile of gas through any disk. High velocity gas at 400 km/s width will be detectable at >4sigma significance in five spatial bins using 20 km/s velocity binning. This sensitivity requires a 1.3hr observation at CO(3-2) for RXJ0821. Based on CASA simdata simulations and Cycle 0 experience, this observation will provide sufficient uv-coverage to image the extended structure.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA CO (3-2) and CO (1-0) imaging and spectroscopy for two brightest cluster galaxies (BCGs) located at the centres of cooling flows. With star formation rates of up to 140 solar masses per year and molecular gas masses exceeding ten billion solar masses, the BCGs are burgeoning and are among the most molecular gas rich galaxies in the universe. The observations are intended to map the dynamics of central gas disks and rings and to detect and characterize molecular gas flows. ALMA Cycle 0 observations of similar systems have revealed giant ~10^10 solar mass flows of molecular gas, at least one of which appears to be outflow and apparently driven by a radio AGN. This is a significant development in our understanding of AGN feedback, and would suggest that radio-mode feedback, which is common to all elliptical galaxies, may be able to sweep elliptical galaxies of their molecular gas, keeping them "red and dead."
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00374.S, Molecular gas and feedback in the cores of galaxy clusters, PI McNamara 2012.1.00837.S, Understanding molecular gas acretion and feedback from supermassive black holes, PI McNamara
